features.description: Option to combine multiple domain validation configurations when working with a single certificate.

list.title: Certify The Web
list.summary: Professional Automated Certificate Management tools, including direct support for Windows/IIS and a wide range of deployment tasks.
list.description: Certify The Web is a suite of tools for ACME certificate management. Products include the popular Certify Certificate Manager (Desktop UI + Service for Windows Server), Certify Management Hub (centralised cross-platform cert management and renewal monitoring web UI) and Certify Management Agent (cross platform agent for cert management and monitoring).
pros: A popular choice on Windows, with hundreds of thousands of users. Certify Certificate Manager is optimised for Windows users, with built-in support for IIS and the windows certificate store.

Certify Management Hub is a new cross platform self-hosted web tool for centralised cert management with role based security and an API. Includes multi-server management and monitoring of renewals managed by selected 3rd party cert managers.
Registered users have access to dedicated helpdesk ticketing.
Support for a wide range of DNS APIs (28+, including many provided via Posh-ACME).
Support multiple auth config (e.g. mixing http and DNS validation, or using multiple DNS providers in one cert).
Extensive range of optional Deployment Tasks to perform scripting or to deploy to Apache, nginx, Azure Key Vault etc.
Support Linux and macOS via the Certify Management Hub and Certify Management Agent products
cons: Commercial users require a license after their evaluation.

list.title: acme.sh
list.summary: Popular acme client written as unix shell script.
list.description: Unlike many other popular clients (which tend to default to using Let's Encrypt), acme.sh defaults to the ZeroSSL certificate authority for certificate orders.
pros: Optimized for Linux and other unix-like systems, broad compatibility
Support for a range of DNS APIs (external dependencies required).
cons: Only limited support for Windows (requires Cygwin or other compatible shells etc)

list.title: Certbot
list.summary: The official ACME client recommended by Let's Encrypt.
list.description: Certbot is a Python based command line tool with native support for Apache and nginx. Support is provided via the Let's Encrypt community site.
pros: Official ACME tool recommended by Let's Encrypt
Optimized for Linux, with built-in deployment options for Apache and nginx
Support for ~14 DNS APIs for DNS validation
cons: Only limited support for Windows (no IIS deployment etc, does not produce/store PFX)
Limited distribution support if not using snap to install

list.title: getssl
list.summary: A client implemented as a Unix (bash) shell script.

list.title: lego
list.summary: A Let's Encrypt/ACME client and library written in Go

list.title: Posh-ACME
list.summary: A PowerShell module and ACME client to create publicly trusted SSL/TLS certificates from an ACME capable certificate authority.
list.description: Posh-ACME is PowerShell module providing a set of cmdlets to work with ACME accounts and to order, validate and fetch certificates.

list.title: win-acme
list.summary: A client tool for the Windows command line.
pros: Optimized for Windows, with built-in deployment options for IIS
cons: No longer maintained by the main developer. Development has moved to the simple-acme fork.

list.title: certmanager
list.summary: ACME certificate management for Kubernetes and OpenShift

list.title: simple-acme

list.title: CertSage
list.summary: A PHP based ACME Client designed for non-root access.
list.description: CertSage is a PHP script which can be installed on existing PHP sites. It is ideal if you are using a shared hosting plan that does not allow root access, such as shared hosting.
pros: Optimized for sites without root access, including shared hosting
Simple installation and management via a web interface
